Reception and Senior staff  Our group of eleven arrived at the hotel after a late evening flight from Aswan for our three day-stay in Cairo.    The hotel was pre-booked by the Tour Company, but the reception staff were not ready to receive us, and we had to wait for over forty minutes until the rooms were allocated. Then we found that the rooms were not allocated as specifically requested. For example,  two single female guests were given a room with a double bed and a couple were given a room with twin beds! This gave the impression that the Reception staff either did not read the information supplied in advance or if they read them, they did not pay due attention to them.   The Reception staff did not appear to have much hospitality experience. The senior staff were rude, unhelpful, and unfriendly both on the telephone and during face-to-face meetings.    Portage The bell boys or porters were not very helpful, and the guests had to carry their own luggage to the rooms. This was significant given that the group members were senior citizens. This was the first time we had experienced poor service in a ‚Äú5-star‚Äù hotel.   Room Service Room service was prompt, house-keeping staff were very helpful and friendly.    Wi-fi Wi-fi connections and signal were excellent in the rooms and elsewhere in the hotel.   Rooms and bathrooms Rooms were spacious and quiet. However, they were outdated with many defects and shortcomings.   Some of the bathrooms did not have hand towels; some had no bath towels. Although there were tea/coffee making facilities, often there were no cups, teaspoons, tea, or coffee. The air conditioning was switched off and had a very unpleasant smell. In one bathroom, the electric wire in the hairdryer was wrapped in sticking plaster! Bathrooms had mould around the walls and round the bath. The tiles were broken or cracked. A common complaint by all the group members was that the bath handles were coming apart,  and dangerous to hold on to getting in and out of the bath. Door handles were loose and could not be closed securely. Some lights bulbs were not working, and some could not be switched off. These had to be turned off at the socket. Some rooms had not been serviced at all. This gave the impression that the supervisors and the managers had not inspected the rooms.    Restaurant and Meals  The Restaurant area was very small for a hotel with several hundred rooms. There was hardly any room to walk between tables once the diners were seated. Breakfast and dinner menus were basic and not much variety. If you went for a late sitting, food ran short. The Senior Restaurant Manager on duty for one evening was extremely rude and shouted at a guest. We had to report this incident to the Director of the Tour Company to resolve the issues. The restaurant waiters worked very hard but due to a shortage of staff, the service was below expectations.   Cleanliness There were bags of leftover food outside the room in the corridor.   Reporting At the end of our stay, we complained to the Assistant Guest Relations Managers Nermine Wagih and Madonna and provided them with a video and pictures of the state of one of the bathrooms. It was interesting that none of the mangers chose to speak to us and apologised for the poor conditions and service. The rooms were spacious with a great view over the Nile (I was too low to able to see the pyramids), the standard was so-so, but you could easily tell that this has some age to it. I would not exactly describe this an luxury hotel, but I do think I might have a bit higher standards. The room also had one of my pet peeves, but I was aware of it: carpets on the floor. The room was also seemingly clean, but I could see a few spot on the carpets that in addition to some dorm bunnies. The A/C worked somehow, but it was difficult to adjust the temperature. The TV in the room didn't work, nor did the mini-bar/fridge in the room. The bathroom were also aged, and it was a bit of a hazard to get in and out of the bathtub/shower. The hair dryer worked nicely. I did have some issues the key cards several times, but it was all easily fixed in the reception.   I did not have any problems with the Wi-Fi, it was very easy to use, and I was a bit reassured when I arrived and saw how it was, as I don't really like an open-open Wi-Fi service. But a lot of my colleagues had more troubles with the Wi-Fi, which I found a bit confusing.   I also payed for breakfast included with the room, the breakfast area in the lobby (Fotana Restaurant) had a lovely view, although it was quite noisy due to the layout. There was a great variety of food and drinks, but it was a hassle to ask the waiter/waitress for plain water everytime. The staff quite quick to remove the plates, but in terms of making the table ready for the next guests were so-so. I also observed that the coffee/tea part were changed during my stay, from self-service on a counter, to the waiter walking a trolley around. I also had breakfast down in the food court as I believe the lobby-area was full at certain time. I have the same remarks for there.  I went around the hotel as I had some free time, it was very nice that the hotel offered two ATM (which was particularly lucky for me, as I could get one of them to work for me). Be aware to get money in cash, there's few places that have changes for bills, especially the restaurant, but at least you have the option to pay by card. I was pleased that there were A/Cs throughout the hotel, but I do question how they were operated, as certain days it was so cold that I was actually freezing in the hotel. The swimming pool area was nice with a great view. The terrace floor was also nice, but completely empty of furniture. I checked some of the gifts shops, which were nice and bought some things since it was so easy, but I do think that the person in charge was a bit too pushy with a bit of a communication problem. I did inquire about the airport transportation - which was quite expensive, so I used a third party service which worked nicely. But for the ease of it, I would consider using the hotel's airport transportation if I traveled here again for the convenience.  During our stay I tried two of the restaurant located in the hotel: The Revolving Restaurant and the El Sakya Souk Restaurant with a group of colleagues. We were most satisfied with the Revolving Restaurant in terms of the food, but the services was better in the El Sakya Souk Restaurant. But the view at the Revolving Restaurant is gorgeous, just a shame that about the air pollution, as I believe it could have been even better without the air pollution. I would not recommend trying the pizza at the El Sakya Souk Restaurant. It is also prudent to remember the 12% service charge + taxes, and there's no alcohol, only non-alcoholic options.   It seemed that the hotel did a lot of things, I could observe at least two weddings during my stay, a lot of tourist groups; and there was some loud music happening in the evenings. In additional to our own conference, the facilities for it was satisfying. There's also quite a lot of smokers in this hotel, especially in the lobby, which was a huge cultural shock as this isn't usual for me/us. Grand Nile Tower is a very busy hotel, lucky I could not hear or sense this in my room. The staff were very friendly and polite, but I do think that there were some communications problems/errors. ‚Ä¶

I'll give you the positives first. The place is clean, has a pleasant lobby with a reading room on the side. As for location, it's within walking distance of the Museum of Egyptian Antiquities and Tahrir Square. The staff is mostly very helpful, BUT... anybody who has traveled in Egypt knows that the quality of customer service varies greatly. In my case, when I was checking out, the woman at the desk told me I had to pay cash. I said, OK, no problem, where's the nearest bank machine? She said, "banks are closed on Sunday." That, of course, was a ridiculous response. Fortunately, another employee within earshot said that there was an ATM around the corner. Turned out that he was wrong, too. There are actually two ATM's a half block down the street. So no problem, but you really have to wonder, how can somebody work in a place and not be aware of where the nearest ATM is? It's important to know that the reception desk is actually on the tenth floor. This isn't an issue during the daytime, because there's a desk at the building entrance. However, if you arrive at 3:30 AM like I did, that desk will be unmanned. I had to bang on the elevator door for a while before the front desk guy became aware of my presence. The staff should really advise people of this when they book for late arrival. Finally, most taxi drivers don't know where the Osiris is. This is no surprise, because most Cairo taxi drivers don't know where anything else is, either. But be sure to have the hotel's business card with you to show the driver, and have the hotel's location on the GPS app on your cell phone.‚Ä¶
